description:
The Saratoga offers excellent food and fabulous cocktails in a very cool atmosphere.  Being the sister restaurant to Spruce, I had very high expectations for the food, and they were completely met.  The two story cocktail bar on the corner is a loud and dark venue with loud music, but it is a fun atmosphere.  Reservations are likely a necessity, and I would never try to come in without them.

The staff is very helpful and attentive.  While a bit slow to take orders, I think that there was an initial deluge and every other need was quickly met.

The venue is elegant but casual.  Because of the dark nature of the place, I didn't feel like a loser in my jeans and sweater, but I also would have been quite comfortable in a dress for a night out on the town.  Expect bistro towel napkins, lacquered tables and Edison lights - ubiquitous but it works.

The drinks are excellent and meet every flavor profile.  Each of us had a drink that we loved, even though we did not necessarily love each other's.  I had the Sibling Rivalry ($15), which was made with Rye, Canton Ginger, St. Germain, Regan's & Peychaud Bitters.  It was a perfectly executed, smooth and toasty drink that made my own day of dealing with sibling rivalry feel SO much better.

Speaking of sibling rivalry, there is no kids' menu but the place it not family prohibitive.  No crayons, but they were served just as well as the rest of us.  The LOs enjoyed having a Chicken Slider ($8 each) and splitting a order of the tomato braised kale ($10).  Both dishes were well prepared and used quality ingredients.

DM and I split the Branzino a la Plancha ($28), which was ridiculously good.  The perfectly cooked and fresh fish had crisp skin and was alongside black forbidden rice and this sweet and roasted Puttanesca sauce that had just the right amount of salt.  We also shared the roasted green beans ($10), which were sweet and crunchy haricots vert tossed in a sweet chili glaze and topped with chopped peanuts.  These were very good, but the Hen of the Woods Mushrooms ($11) were OUT OF THIS WORLD! 6-8 crunchy fried and woodsy mushrooms were practically meaty and were pushed over the top with a tangy and creamy lemon aioli.  I wanted to order some for dessert but thought that might be pushing my belly over the top.

The prices are pretty average for San Francisco - expensive for the rest of the world - but the food and cocktail program shines in a city known for excellence in both.  I would definitely come again.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Came in for my birthday. The service was decent, but the service downstairs was outstanding. Was looking for the bathroom, and the bartenders knew what I was looking for, and told me where I needed to go. 

And yeah, the burger and fries were good and arrived within 10 minutes.
author: Pickle R.

description:
***Only been here for weekend brunch***

I came because it was on the Eater Brunch list and my friend told me that their burgers are one of the best in the city. That I would agree with, the burger was really good and they cut it in half for us knowing we wanted to share everything. Was a very nice touch. 

MUST GET: Burger. If you don't like very strong cheeses, i'd recommend that you ask if you can change the one they usually put on there or just take it out.

DON'T GET: Billionare's bacon unless you have 4 or more people to share it with. It's very thick and very fatty. The first bite was awesome with an explosion of fattiness but the 2nd and 3rd just became too oily and fatty that I felt gross after. French Toast was disappointing. It's a huge portion and was really mushy and not crispy on the edges either. The syrup they made was too strong in bourbon. 

I've heard great things about their dinner so maybe i'll come back to try that and see if its better!
author: Rohenne L.

description:
My friend and I greatly appreciated that their kitchen serves brunch later than most restaurants, up to 3 pm. I had been meaning to come here for dinner or cocktails, but they were the only ones open near an event we were heading to. It seemed like there was only one server and one bartender to take care of the five to six tables and parties at the bar, yet they still managed to be attentive - even apologetic for a slight wait. They gave us a sort of alcoholic amuse bouche that tasted like sparkling wine to tide us over as we waited for our actual drinks. I was impressed with the presentation of my drink with a perfect egg white foam, but sadly the flavors didn't quite work with gin, watermelon, and something extremely sour.

The brunch menu is limited, but well-executed. Simple parts like the English green peas with the benedict or the sauce on the cheeseburger were impressive on their own. It is pricey for the short list of dishes, though. The restaurant and bar areas are nice both upstairs and downstairs, and the bathroom is one of the nicest I have been in.
author: Cat N.

description: Great cocktails, great atmosphere, they have two bars and most importantly not too crowded like other bars in San Francisco. I recommend this place.
author: Madhu J.

description: Had an ok time here, would just come here for drinks and maybe a bite or two in the future, not a full sit down meal. Ambiance is ok, but since we didn't have reservations, we sat at the smaller tables on the 2nd floor (too low for the chairs provided!). Service was so-so, ambiance is kinda whatever in my opinion. We shared several bites, the mexican street corn (eh), the fried green tomatoes (too much batter), and the crispy hen of the woods (batter was too similar to the fried green tomatoes) and the mushrooms were way thick, would have preferred smaller slices. Might return just for drinks, and not a full meal.
author: Vivian D.

description:
I've been eyeing the Saratoga for so long, and despite my friends' complaints about its unsavory location on the outskirts of the 'Loin, I managed to drag them here for dinner. There's a downstairs area as well as their main area, and when I arrived at 6pm on Friday, most of the spots at the bar were full but there were still tables empty. The dimness, heavy chairs, and attire of the waiters makes the place seem swanky and luxurious.

I'm surprised not many people have tried the Boothby Bowls at this place (or written about them), but the $100 price tag is a bit off-putting. The four of us decided to chance it anyway, considering all cocktails are $14 anyway, and ordered the Jalisco Spa Treatment. It arrived in a huge vase with a spigot, a thing of beauty. It also tasted so delicious and refreshing - I would gladly get drunk every day of my life if it meant I could drink this stuff instead of Kirkland vodka. The best part was that each of us got a good 5 glasses out of the bowl, so you can definitely try this with a bigger group if it seems expensive! 

For food, we ordered a number of small bites, including the soft pretzel, 'Toga Tots, hen-of-the-woods mushrooms, asparagus salad, and shoestring fries. Everything was so good! The cheese dip that came with the soft pretzel wasn't super thick and had this delicious, deep flavor. The tots were my favorite, with the saltiness of chorizo and a satisfying crunchy outer layer. I also really enjoyed the asparagus salad, which had a creamy but light dressing and a nice crispness. The only thing I thought wasn't that great were the fries because they weren't super hot when we got them, but they were great for filling us up.

Our waitress was just the right amount of attentive, and the check came to around $50 per person.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Super cute and hot spot, walking distance from Union Square if you don't mind to walk through a little sketchy part of town.

Two level, beautifully designed. Love the gorgeous bar with an amazing selection of liquor and spirits. 

According to them "The cocktail and spirits program features a grand selection of "lost and forgotten" spirits, such as Chartreuse, Fernet, Pimm's and Benedictine, dating back to the 1920s and 1930s. The nearly 800-selection-long spirits list is also particularly deep in bourbon, scotch and rye whiskies. In addition, a well-curated cocktail list is broken down into subcategories: Highballs, Bottled & Barreled, Shaken, Stirred, and "Cocktail Bill" Boothby Bowls." That's impressive.

Awesome handcrafted cocktails list, trust the bartender and ask them to make you what you like.

Smaller wine list but well for by the glass, we enjoyed it.

Food was solid. We enjoyed the Street Corn in a Cup
Berbere-Spiced Aioli, Feta, Chili Powder dish the most. 

The 'Toga Tots Fiscalini Cheddar, Chorizo, Cilantro was good. 

Chicken Liver Pâté Strawberry, Peppercorn, Endive Slaw, Candied Walnut was on point.

Roasted Green Beans Toasted Almonds, Thai Chile Glaze, our second favorite dish here. So simple, but so darn tasty! 

The Saratoga Burger Taleggio Cheese, Slaw, Onion Bun, was good, but I wish it has tomato or some citrus.

It was during Google Next and SNIS Conferences week, they were packed with corporate. We were at the bar... a little slow but the bartender was nice. 

They need to fix the chairs at the bar, it's unbalanced and crooked. 

I put the pix on IG, and their social media people thank you right away. Good work that you care about your guests. We'll definitely be back.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
Came here for a double date night and was impressed by the beautiful interior and the extensive cocktail/whiskey menu. 

We shared the tater tots, the chicken pate and the pretzels. The chicken pate was most excellent, with a perfect mix of sweet and savory with the saltiness of the pate and the sweetness of the stewed strawberries. The toast and the walnuts give the dish a nice contrast in textures. I wasn't too into the pretzels, though my it wasn't soft enough and the cheese dip was pretty average. The tater tots were great, too. There's basically cheese whiz and bacon bits on top. 

For entrees, we had the steak, the halibut, the burger and the hotdog. I went halfsies with my friend for the burger and hotdog and both were excellent. So juicy and flavorful and the buns were nicely soft to soak up the deliciousness. The hotdog also had thinly sliced roast pork. The table also shared the fries (claimed to be shoestring fries but they're just regular fries and aight, nothing to write home about) and the Mexican Street corn. I didn't really tried the corn but my friend liked it. 

For dessert, we shared the scotch pudding and the funnel cake. Incidentally, the pudding is a perfect dip for the funnel cake because the two dips that came with the funnel cake wasn't great. The chartreuse sugar dip was disgusting, gross gross cough syrup and neon green/blue. The chocolate sauce was just ok. We all ended up just smearing the scotch pudding all over the funnel cake and it was great. 

I don't even remember what drinks the group ordered, but it was a lot. I am pregnant so only had a a virgin drink, some sort of lemony and tarragon concoction that was a bit too tart and not all that complex. My friend had their famous burning pineapple drink and she liked it. Most of their drinks were pretty boozy and the gentlemen also sampled a few of the offerings on the whiskey menu. 

We are upstairs but went downstairs to check out their lovely bar. I actually wish we were seated downstairs because it was quieter. The service was great, too, people came by to pour water a few times and we never wanted for anything. I like how they have a small menu, too. All in all, great experience and will come back when they update their menu for the season.
author: Alice W.

description:
We came here for Easter brunch. It was easy enough to get a reservation (even the night before).

The service was a little off, we (and they) were confused as to who was our server.  Once it was all sorted - my husband and I got the french toast and the breakfast sandwich of the day (a Cuban hot dog with an egg) and a side of billionaire bacon (all to split).

Our friend ordered the Jenga tots (HUGE!!!) -- a life-sized Jenga tower of about 12-15 LARGE tater tots - served with lox, capers and sour cream

I wanted to love the hot dog - for me it was too over-loaded to enjoy. The French toast was good and the billionaire bacon was the highlight for me (really just pork belly) - I used the leftovers on a home-made pizza the next night and it was a hit!

I would love to come back for dinner.

The room and the bathrooms are beautiful (but in the heart of the not-so-great tenderloin). The wine list is HUGE.
author: Amy W.

description: We stopped in before a concert for a couple drinks and some apps. We didn't have reservations, but we're still seated promptly. We knew going in it was pricey, but at the end, worth it. The food was great, drinks were delicious, service was excellent. All those things considered we would definitely come back, next time for a full meal.
author: Adan F.

description:
I have been to Saratoga several times and enjoyed it. I tend to sit at the bar and order drinks and appetizers and it's always been consistent. But, today the experience blew me away. 

Emily was working the downstairs bar (and I thought I had recognized her from Spruce), but her cocktails and skill level are at the top in this city. We watched her make over 20 cocktails and she was both creative and personable. Her drinks looked like art and were they were perfectly balanced. Wow, she is a reason to come back! If you haven't had the pleasure I recommend coming in right away!
author: melissa l.

description:
I thought this place was great from the jump. Classy, chic, and somewhat mysterious on the outside, it can easily be overlooked. But don't let yourself make that mistake. Walking in, you see a beautifully decorated bar that has all the accoutrement one could possibly need OR want in their dining experience. (They even ordered a shaker for one of their gin drinks, which delivers the most beautiful, fluffiest, DELICIOUS shaken, Gin Ramos Fizz's I have ever seen.)

Each time I have gone there, it's been nothing but a delightful experience. First, for dinner in the downstairs seating area - somewhat recluse and perfectly romantic. Having been in the service industry myself for 15+ years, I'm picky. And nothing was amiss. Luckily, we've been acquainted with the manager here, Mandy, and she literally runs around making sure everything is perfect. Her attention to detail, her culinary creations behind the scenes are not to be left unnoticed. This place no doubt owes a lot of its smooth-running success to her. And we couldn't be more grateful :)

We've also gathered for drinks and late night snacks (more specifically, the harissa fries with a yummy yogurt dipping sauce. It's a late night go-to, and the bowl is big enough for 3. Maybe even more) in the lounge area, and keep coming back for more. Til date, I have been there more times than I can count, and it's worth it every time.

What you can't miss? BRUNCH. And little known tip? They're open for Saturdays too! Less busy, not as much of a wait, and still just as mouthwatering-ly delicious. (I'm not exaggerating, you guys. Go see for yourself.) 

WHAT WE ORDERED (I'm going to include both brunches here, so don't think I'm a fatass and ordered this all at once) :

THE JENGA TOTS: it's a feast for your eyes AND your stomach. It's a MUST if you're dining here for the first time. The presentation is beyond beautiful, and will capture diner's eyes from all over the room. You wouldn't think the taste could compete with the visual appeal, but alas. It more than delivers. 


THE FRENCH TOAST: THE BEST FT I HAVE EVER HAD (I am not lying. They accidentally brought it out with the bacon crumble ontop, but instead of returning it - we just got another one so we didn't have to share. One w/ bacon for him - one without for me.)

THE EGGS BENEDICT (substituted ham for salmon): So delicious w/ the pretzel bun, but I feel like I would've still been hungry if I didn't order something else. So go to town and order all your heart desires!!


DRINKS: 
BLOODY MARY w/ JALAPENO POPPERS: Mmmmm POP! Nothing like a drink that comes w/ snacks!

**THE STRAWBERRY-RHUBARB GIN RAMOS** (probably my favorite drink I've had ALL YEAR.) The shaker machine is used here, and it tastes like the lightest milkshake/cocktail/fruity but NOT too sweet drink. Perfection in a glass. Can't wait to have more!!

THE PINK LADY: My boyfriend loved it, but I was too caught up with my Gin Fizz to steal too many sips. Can't go wrong.

THE ROOT & VERDE BLOODY MARY'S: not my favorite, I felt they were a bit sweet, but again - the boyfriend loved it, so nothing went to waste here.

PROSECCO: seems basic, but delightfully light and refreshing. Would 100% order again.


Ok, I've rambled on for a bit - but you get the idea. Go to Saratoga, order all the things. And have Nikki, Alan, or Jeff make you some of the best cocktails you've ever had. The END.
author: Tiba G.

description:
Here for a casual Friday night date. 

Had a reservation, but restaurant was half empty. Good ambiance and service.

This is probably more of a drink place rather than food place. Our foods were good, but overpriced. The toga tots (4 stars) were good. The sauce of the chicken liver toast was a bit too sweet, which overcame the taste of the liver (3 stars). Roasted chicken (4 stars) was good but nothing special and the side of french beans was a little too heavy in the sauce for my taste but the flavor was food (3.5 stars).

TLDR: the food was good but nothing stood out. 4 stars for food but 3 stars considering price and value.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
Came here for brunch after finding out they had cereal milk punch (my fiancé is on a hunt to try every type of cereal/milk tea punch in the city apparently)

We got the jenga tots, mimosa donut, side of eggs, and cereal milk punch (we knew the order of tots were huge so we didn't order two mains).

Overall the jenga tots were good, though they're pretty heavy handed with the cream cheese. We were scraping it off the tots just so avoid it, and I think I'm good off cream cheese for the rest of the year lol. The mimosa donut was good, but don't be fooled, it did not taste or vaguely taste like a mimosa at all. It's a very dense donut if you like that type too. 

Cereal milk punch was pretty good, a strong drink but you could still taste the flavor. In our journey to try all milk punches in the city, I'd rate this above The Kabuki Bar but below Eight Tables (which has thai milk tea punch for the best $22 you'll ever spend on a single cocktail). 

Pricing: pretty expensive for what they're serving, but it's SF so I guess it's fine? Seems like brunch and overpriced go hand in hand now anyway so this place is priced just the same as everywhere else. 

+1 star for service too! My fiancé (can't take him anywhere smh) tried playing actual jenga with the tots and a tot and a huge piece of salmon fell on the floor. The waitress cleaned it up quickly and even brought back more salmon for us!
author: Jillian Y.

description:
When my gorgina glamazon goddess friendgirl who recently relocated from Miami told me that that this place in SF came close to matching the Miami Vice(s) scene in terms of glam, first I worried about her mental health. Then I decided to check mine and set up our next GNO.

I dusted off my furs, anticipated her Ellery, and we alerted our one other faboosh fashionista friend, who I shall reference as Gucci Womane for obvious reasons. Any given time 250 in her grill. (She iced out but she don't got snow man.)

Our triumvirate was complete. Off to the trap house. 

The space didn't disappoint. Beautiful light fixture and sexy double story bar space with limited seating upstairs, more ample space downstairs. 

We were introduced to the Green Goblin, a chartreuse based herbal basil cocktail that was delicious and topped with cherries. 

Shout out to the  bartender launching his inaugural Saratoga career that made these, I forgot your name (job well done) but you had a very successful first day. At least, that's what AmEx tells me (15$/cocktail!)

We also had small bites: Chicken Slider, Carrot Salad, and Hamachi Crudo. I opted for the carrot salad and it was an excellent savory complement to da 'gob. 

Definitely would return! "What's a goon to a goblin?"
author: Spartevan V.

description:
Location is eh. But really easy to get to. 

We went for brunch and were seated in the area downstairs which has this amazing speakeasy feel to it. The wait staff was amazing and provided such a good experience. The food and drinks were amazing!!!

Firstly, that tater tot jenga thing is amazing. It has all kinds of salmon, capers and other goodies on it. I ordered whatever was on the special along with trying just about everything else that my friends ordered and they were all delicious. 

I would love to come again for lunch or dinner.
author: Michael P.

description:
A restaurant good enough to interrupt a blistering coke bender. Easily the best food in the Tenderloin. Bar None. Better than ORSON used to be. Professional service from cool people. Great interior. 

The weakness of this place is the shitty tables -- and if you're interrupted mid-bender.--the goddam yakking of dorks & morons in every direction.

BEST CHICKEN LIVER PÂTÉ IN CALIFORNIA.
BEST FRIED GREEN TOMATOES IN SF.
BEST YELLOWTAIL CRUDO IN SF.

They know how to trim and cook a strip steak. 
THANKS SARATOGA.

I meant better than the tastier than Orson place called HUXLEY. (It wasn't you, Hux, it was The World. Nay, ''twas the wicked and corrupt 21st century American Lameness and silver car SAMENESS that killed you. Your hood and forced intimacy was robot averse.)

Yes: Saratoga is bigger & better. Looking and Tasting.
author: James D.

description:
A little pricy depending what you order but great food and atmosphere. Its in an old historic 2 story building thats been around almost 150 years. Theres bars up top and down below in a modern atmosphere with some funky jazz music going. I ordered their famous burger with loaded tots and a few mix drinks.

Iv been to all the best burger spots in the bay and this ones a close 2nd. Quality bun, 2 rare and juicy patties, salty taleggio cheese, and im usually not big on slaw but it complimented the flavors nicely. The togo tots rocked as well. They come stacked in cube shapes that look sorta like fried tofo instead of your standard tots and covered in cheese and chorizo.

 For drinks they have hundreds of options including rare discontinued liquors. i had a walking dead and a bourban highball. The bourban was good. It was mixed with cherry vanilla and cola. My favorite was the walking dead tho. Rum, lemon, papaya, pineapple, pomegranate, and tiki bitters served on fire with pinapple. They make the drinks strong here too.

All around a great experiance check this place out!
author: Sean G.

description:
Excellent dinner last night with the Restaurant week prefixed menu- though I thought it was weird they didn't let you choose between options for your main. The carrot salad definitely had a Far East flavor profile, hints of cumin and maybe allspice, balances with Greek yogurt drizzle. Very tasty and refreshing to balance out the tots (which are more like hush puppies). I wasn't blown away by them honestly, but they were pretty good with some chopped bacon, chives and an aioli. 

The short rib for the main was phenomenal! Served on a bed of creamy polenta (or grits, are they one in the same?) with some arugula to cut through the heaviness. The short rib was perfectly cooked, crispy outside with a tender and juicy inside). I do think that another acid could have been added to cut through the fat, perhaps pickled onions or something. I asked for a side of hot sauce to get some heat in there (and their hot sauce was amazing, sort of a chicory smoked bbq sauce). 

We asked for some pork rolls on the side which were puffy, warm, salty and fabulous; but I didn't care much for the pimento spread it was served with. I think it could've benefited from an herb infused butter instead like rosemary or basil. 

Dessert was delicious and super heavy, not for the faint hearted. Chocolate ho ho with a crisped marshmallow spread base! The chocolate cake was moist with great fudge-y consistency. Drinks were very strong, and very expensive (2 totaled to more than the meal). Folks next to use ordered the burger, octopus and chicken escalope, and all said they were prepared perfectly and tasted sensational (pics included). 

The atmosphere of the place is great. Open dining area, beautiful dark/modern design, great upbeat music- perfect for a date or night out with friends. Staff was friendly, not really notable in an either good or bad way. Will definitely return after my bank account recovers
author: Tash B.

description:
Solid 4 stars for a great restaurant week experience!

We came here tonight for dinner.  The venue is super cool - all black decor with an awesome chandelier in the middle of the restaurant, which hovers over the stairs that take you to downstairs seating.  There is a massive bar with a great alcohol suggestion and the overall vibe is very swanky.

We had a seat near the front and immediately were helped with what we wanted to drink (cocktails) and eat (restaurant week meal).

We started off with the Himachi.  It was very delicious, with three pieces of fish accompanied by mushrooms, apples, and delicious sauce.  Overall very good.

Second course was a choice of Toga Tots or a Carrot Salad.  Now I'm a tater tots gal, but am trying to get more vegetables in the mix these days.  Therefore, the hubby and I ordered one of each.  The Tots were AMAZING.  More like fried potato cubes with delicious sauce on top.  Small portion but the perfect amount if you don't want to be bogged down by fried foods.  The carrot salad was also AMAZING.  I actually hate carrots generally, but these were deliciously seasoned and grilled with avocado and a yogurt sauce.  Honestly I could have eaten a massive plate of those carrots.

Last savoury course was a generous short rib on top of grits in a delicious dark sauce.  It was perfectly cooked - moist and fatty - and was a great short rib.  I do wish the sauce was slightly sweeter, but overall was great.  We also had a great syrah which paired very nicely with the dish.

For dessert, we had a Hoho which tasted very much like a hoho.  It also had chopped up caramel pretzels which were delicious.  A pretty sweet dessert but not very heavy.

Will definitely be back here - even if just for a cocktail!
author: Jade R.

description:
Had an amazing dinner here a few months back. Two people, seated upstairs. 

Our server was Sophie; she was incredibly helpful, friendly, knowledgeable and fast.

We had:
Parker rolls - amazing!
Shoestring fries - amazing!
Asparagus - amazing
Steak - amazing

We were in a hurry to get to a movie after and they awesomely packed an order of the cracker jacks for us to go.

It was an overall awesome experience and a place I'm happy to keep going back to.
author: Ryan B.

description:
If it was a little less expensive I would've given it 4, but for the price I would recommend going to other places for dinner.

However, if want a spot for drinks and go and light food it's a good choice. The tater tots are super good but they should increase the number of tots you get. 

Food we ordered:

Tots - so damn good. Would've ordered another round.
Fries - okay but not worth getting, just get the tots.
Burger - no flavor. Pass.
Frank cubano - good but not amazing. I've eaten better things elsewhere. 

Drinks:

Walking dead - good, but sweet! Presentation was awesome (flaming pineapple)
The avenue - good, but sweet bourbon drink.
author: I S.

description: This review is long overdue. I had an amazing birthday day for a friend here a year ago and everything was great. From the music to the vibe to the food, it was easy to see this would be our spot. Recently, I went back to try their happy hour and it was bangin. I'm telling everyone. Saratoga HH- nothing better.
author: Ayanna A.

description:
Wow! Fantastic brunch! Absolutely gorgeous restaurant. The bar is stunning. Ambience fun, hip and sophisticated. Wonderful brunch menu. Great upstairs table with view of bar and windows looking out on Street. I can't wait to come back for dinner. The downstairs dining room (brunch is served upstairs) is absolutely beautiful, with another stunning bar. A perfect place to go for a drink some evening. Must try the billionaires bacon. The best I've had. The burger juicy and delicious. Jenga tots with smoked salmon is a must. Nothing like it anywhere. The avocado toast had fish roe sprinkled on-top.... so good! 

Now for the cocktails. We had the Hail Mary. A delicious Bloody Mary with add-ons. I had beef jerky, fried pickle and shrimp added... delicious! 
The Sommelier  was super welcoming, knowledgeable and easy to talk too. She gave us an education on chartreuse. No doubt one of the best bourbon lists  in The City. They are offering a McCallum food pairing night which looks delicious and fun. I will come back for dinner where I will start with a bourbon tasting at the bar then dinner in the beautiful dining room. For quality food, amazing cocktails, exemplary service and a speakeasy ambience.... a home run.
author: Ann D.

description: Great customer service. We had the tapas for the happy hour menu and all of it was really really good. I will return and come back again.
author: Ryan O.

description:
Alright people this place is freaking awesome! First off the staff is very professional and friendly and know what they are talking about and secondly, gonna get right into it the "BEST BILLIONAIRE BACON" so juicy, yummy and scrumptious. Definitely a MUST TRY.

Me and a friend went here for brunch and had a great time, we walked in without a reservation and still no wait time which was really nice! Really nice decor and ambience, the tables/seating is a little too close to each other so we could hear the neighbors and I'm sure they heard us too.

We got the sandwich of the day which is a cubano hot dog with egg, I don't really like cubano but it was our fault since our waitress asked us if we wanted to know the ingredients or just surprise us, we chose the latter so I'm not gonna hold them to it. Also got the flautas, which was alright, could use a little more spicy sauce/ flavor. We also got the donut, forget the name but it was yummy, but not the super soft dont if thats what you are looking for.

We also got the vieux carre, which was one of the best I have had so far. They have a huge wine list, didn't get to try it but definitely will next time. So definitely want to go back for the dinner time and try the food and drinks here. It is a little expensive but we were mentally prepared so all in all a good time.
author: Darshana S.

description: Absolutely enjoyed having brunch here! The Hail Mary Bloody Mary was an amazing experience. It's a meal in itself with very creative food skewers. Loved the tater tot jenga, too. The library of whiskeys is impressive as well. Highly recommend!
author: Elisa B.

description:
Dark, swanky & sexy... A bustling two level restaurant, The Saratoga serves up contemporary american cuisine that will satisfy all of your taste buds!  

Some of the outstanding menu items I tried:
Michelada Mussels: 4/5
Street Corn: 5/5
Green Tomato Burrata: 5/5
Prime Dry Aged Rib Eye: 5/5

It's get pretty packed here on a friday night!  Who knew it was so happening in the T-loins?!!
author: Melanie N.

description: In an area of the city that does not have many good choices - this bar is a jewel. The concept is clear, provide some few but upscale food options along with some bar food and then focus on fine spirits and cocktails. After starting of with beers paired with roasted nuts and beef Jerky, we chose their signature burger [basically a cheeseburger] and the Cuban hotdog loaded with what you put in the Cuban sandwich. The highlight were clearly the cocktails we had - all freshly made ingredients and upscale liquor. Along with the upscale atmosphere a 5* cocktail bar experience.
author: Chris Z.

description:
The Saratoga has been written up by so many place that we needed to check it out for our latest dinner club with friends.  It's definitely more of a bar than an actual restaurant as their drink menu looked like the bible.

The appetizers of pretzel bite, toga tots and hot link set a good layer for our main meal.  The link had a nice kick to it.  For the main meal I ordered the dry aged NY and while it was good it wasn't worth the price as I've had better elsewhere.  The sides of brussels sprouts and fries were really good though.

I'd check our The Saratoga on a date night versus a larger group.
author: Blake B.

description:
Go check this place really cool and nice 
Carrot salad amazing Himachi wow 
Thank you
author: Sanfrancisco O.

description:
SF Restaurant Week at The Saratoga did not disappoint ! 

The Hamachi Crudo to start was fabulous, fresh and a must-have. I loved the Warm Chantenay Carrot Salad on the prix fixe menu so much I ordered seconds off the regular menu! 

I was not as in love with my main course, the Red Wine-Braised English-Cut Short Rib. Though it was really good it was a little too fatty for me to fully enjoy. I would not order again. 

Last but certainly not least, the Ho Hos dessert was one of the best desserts I have ever had. A gourmet take on a Ho Ho that has hints of s'more flavors with a rich chocolate outer layer. If I hadn't already been so full from ordering seconds of the carrot salad believe me I would've ordered seconds of this! 

Make sure you reserve or ask for a seat downstairs. The acoustics of the main floor / upper floor provides for a very loud, unconversational experience. We asked to be moved downstairs and it was worlds better. 

I did not get a chance to dip into the wide array of spirits they gorgeously display but I'll be sure to be back to try their infamous cocktails (and to of course, order more hamachi crudo, carrot salad and ho hos)!
author: Rachel P.

description:
WE WERE RIPPED OFF!! Our waiter brought out an extra order of the tater tots "since your drinks were taking long" and then ADDED THE ORDER TO OUR BILL. She then proceeded to bring out TWO orders of the bread, which we did not order, also playing it off like she was giving us a little extra. These too were added to our bill. In the end the food was not good and we paid far too much for it. Don't come here to eat. 

No idea how this place is rated 4.5 stars except that the cocktails are decent, and they have an extensive spirits menu.

The only thing that saved this evening was the company at my table, but it would have been an evening much better spent somewhere else.
author: Christiana L.

description: Pretty cool venue on the cusp of the Tenderloin. The food is soooooo good and the cocktails are delish! I also really like the layout a lot. My favorite thing to eat so far is the sea bass. Holy Moses!!! Crispy skin and juicy fish!!! Love, love LOVE IT!!!!!
author: Ali R.

description: Drink selection and prices very good, overall fair deal considering location and a great atmosphere. I had the strip (very over cooked) and green beans (delicious). Probably not going back for food.
author: Gary P.

description:
i didnt expect to love the saratoga as much as i did! have been here for cocktails prior - but wasnt super impressed by the quality and they are quite pricey at $14 a pop. but i was craving a burger and boi was kind enough to oblige so we came here for brunch with a specific goal in mind - the saratoga burger, as seen on quite a few 'top xxyyzz' lists in sf and regionally.  restaurant wasnt as busy as i had anticipated on a sunny sunday and we walked in to get seated right away without a reservation. the bar (both upstairs and downstairs) is a good option if you dont have a ressie as well. 

ordered a brunch cocktail to start - something orange-y and fizzy, but i wasnt impressed.  at $14 i expected a bit more. also i wish i enjoyed bloody marys - they have quite the line up and topping options! boi ordered the boozy house coffee and really enjoyed that! great presentation on both, i must say.  he also said that the coffee is delicious on its own and didnt need any booze, per se.

we obviously both got the burger, and shared an order of the jenga tater tots with smoked salmon.  super happy with both!  the jenga tots were pricey at $23 for an 'appetizer' but it was unique and tasted so good. the tots themselves were super crispy on the outside and the potatoes are shredded on the inside - amazing. traditional lox and toppings as adornments on the tots.  the presentation is also hard to beat and truly instagram worthy.  i will be ordering the half order next time as we had several tots left over.. sad face* 

now - the BURGER. is. so good. that is it. i didnt feel overly guilty for devouring the thing in about 6 minutes. i migggghhhhttt like it more than the charter oak burger, actually! TBD. right amount of cheese, slaw, good thin patties, cooked well, good bun. 100%.  would come back just for this.

we also had incredibly great service during brunch, and im sorry i dont recall her name. but usually brunch is such a rushed affair in sf with long waits and customer bumping shoulders in crowded spaces - this was a refreshing change! our waitress was sweet, accommodating, attentive, and super helpful when i asked where the water classes were from.

life hack - stop by mr. holmes around the corner before your reservation to pick up some dessert items and/or breakfast next day! nommzzzz.
author: Christina L.

description:
Came here for drinks with a friend on a Wed night. We arrived a little after 7 and didn't have any trouble snatching two spots at the bar.

I started out with the Free Trade Agreement ($14), which is pisco, cachaça, singani, lemon, agave, egg white, bitters. Presentation was spot on and I really liked the layer of whipped egg white foam on top. It was light and refreshing but I wanted it to be a little bit less sour and more sweet.

I also ordered the Gin highball ($14), which is honeydew, tarragon, lemon, tonic. I'm a sucker for anything fruit flavored, and honeydew is one of my favorites, so I really enjoyed this drink. This was probably my favorite drink from all the drinks we tried here.

My friend ordered the Japanese blended highball ($14), which is yuzu, mint, and soda. I took a test sip, and the yuzu flavor wasn't as strong as I expected. Given that we were both excited about this drink because of the yuzu element, it was a bit of a letdown.

We had already eaten previously so we just grabbed some harissa spiced shoe string fries ($8) to munch on with our drinks. This was surprisingly tasty, and we ended up finishing most of the fries by the end of our time here.

I like that it was pretty spacious here; there was an upstairs bar/dining area as well as an additional bar area downstairs. 

I enjoyed my experience here but don't think the drinks were compelling enough to to make me want to come back, at least not until I've tried some of the other bars around the city.
author: Dianna H.

description:
I've been stalking the Saratoga's menu since they opened. Along with Black Cat, it's definitely part of the New 'Loin. 

Came here on a weeknight (Wed) for a drink. It was pretty crowded but we were able to get a table for 3 for drinks. Seems like most people who go make reservations so take note.

The space is gorgeous and the bar on the first floor is really impressive. Downstairs is quieter and also has a bar. Feels very high brow but the hostesses and bartenders were really nice.

I had the Avenue and a glass of Rosé. I liked both of my drinks and the wine was a suggestion from our server. Drinks are around $14-17 which is on the high side and bill adds up quickly even without food. 

We didn't have food this time but the dishes coming out of the kitchen were seriously envy worthy. I want to try their burger at some point soon.

One star off because this restaurant, like many recently arrived establishments in the nabe, is painfully homogenous and feels like stepping into another world from the neighborhood steps away. I hope they seriously consider who they hire, train and hire people from the neighborhood, consider diversity in staffing, look at the racial disparity between the front of the house and the back of the house, donate leftover food to shelters, etc. etc.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
I only came in for a drink and a small bite and everything was fantastic. I had the "free trade agreement" - which was like a pisco with egg froth cocktail. It was delicious and refreshing. 
I ordered toga tots and that was a wonderful surprise. I think they were tots made in house. First, they were square (which I never see square tots), and second they just tasted so fresh and home made. It was wonderful. 
Service was really good, ambiance is sleek. I'd def come back for a full meal.
author: Veronica L.

description: Great place!  The Saratoga Burger is seriously one of the best burgers I've ever had.  I'm posting a stock photo, bc it's better than my sorry ass dark photo.  Excellent bourbon selection.  Really nice atmosphere.  Good job, Saratoga!!
author: David B.

description: You wanna know what happens when a bunch of teachers have a conference in San Francisco? They dress fancy and go out! Since I was so impressed with this place the last time I was there (see previous review), I took my work peeps to the Saratoga. We had a blast! We drank, we ate, and good times were had. Thank you Saratoga for making me look like a sophisticated city girl. Everyone was so impressed (with the two story decor and the unique drink selection) that we are hoping to go back. Luckily, there is another conference scheduled for 2019. #girlsnightout #didIjusthastag #dohastagsworkonYELP #idkidcare
author: Jennifer C.

description:
There was a happy hour being held here with a few friends, so a friend and I dropped by. We came around 5:30ish, and wasn't too crowded. But def picked up as the evening went on. The ambiance is very classy..it's a mix of a nice bar and sit-down dinner area split between upstairs and downstairs. The space isn't too big, but our happy hour group was about 20-30 of us and we held cozily mixed between both floors.

We stuck around the bar, and the bartender was helpful in recommending drinks for us. Even when it got pretty busy the bartender somehow was always able to help us out and take our orders. There's a great variety of highballs, barreled & bottled, stirred, and shaken. They also have an extensive menu for different types of bourbons, whiskeys, gins, reds, whites, you name it. I can imagine for those who love trying diff types of bourbons would love to visit here. Being an old-fashioned bourbon fan, the bartender recommended I try something a little different, and suggested the Brooklyn. It was Bourbon, Dry Vermouth, Amer Picon, and Maraschino. All I can say was that it was delicious! Apparently the green goblin is popular as well, so my friend ordered that which has Botanical Vodka, Green Chartreuse, Maurin Quina, Lime, and Basil. I personally wasn't a fan of it, but maybe it's because I just really enjoy bourbon. Another friend ordered gin which has Honeydew, Tarragon, Lemon, and Tonic. That was also okay, but I wanted want to order that myself. All that to say, there are a ton of different drinks to try, so pace yourself and have fun. And if you like bourbon, please try the Brooklyn..you won't regret it :) 

Service is fantastic..bartenders, servers, hostess..everyone was quick to help and accommodate such a large group without reservations. Will bring friends here again for another happy hour!
author: Jackie C.

description: The burgers are so damn good. I got one for dinner and then got one to go, and ate it for breakfast the next day.
author: Love F.

description: We had a bad experience with the hostess when we first came in but the rest of the staff really did a great job making sure we were taken care of for drinks. The drinks were really wonderful too. But honestly we we really appreciated the care the rest of the staff showed us after the issues we had starting out.
author: 73and9 7.

description: Went back for the Billionaire's Bacon...OMG...it was just amazing.  In my previous review I said they make the best Eggs Benedict we have had anywhere in the world.  They were just as good the second time.  I ordered poached eggs with the Bacon and they make the most perfect poached eggs I have ever had.  The eggs themselves are very rich and flavorful and they poach them to a runny perfection.  There is not a trace of water.  Service remains superb.  Shout out to Mandy, the manager, and the rest of the team.
author: Robert M.

description:
Came here with a friend to have some drinks before dinner. I love the decor, so glam and modern. The bar is gorgeous. We got in around 630pm and it was packed. Order the drinks at the bar. The bartender was great, forgot his name but he is from NYC. So friendly and I can watch him make drinks all night long. Very crafted and reason why I love the experience so much. If I am paying for a $12-$15 dollar cocktail I rather have it crafted. The cocktails are $14 dollars here but honestly worth every dollar. I got the Free-Trade Agreement. The prettiest drink ever and tasted amazing. Attention to detail is on point. I can't wait to come back and try everything else. 

FYI there is a wait to sit at the bar as well as the restaurant seating. Got a seat at the bar about 15 mins later. Not bad at all.
author: Sandy B.

description:
The Saratoga has been seriously high on the list for a long time. My friend and I checked it out on a Tuesday night. We made a reservation for 7pm one day in advance.

The menu has 20+ pages, all but 2 of them are for drinks. I got the Walking Dead (Rum, Lemon, Papaya, Pineapple, Pomegranate, Tiki Bitters) and she had the Free-Trade Agreement (Pisco, Cachaça, Singani, Lemon, Agave, Egg White, Bitters). Both were beautiful and I liked hers more than mine.

We started with the Toga Tots that everyone seems to rave about. Perhaps our expectations for them were too high; they were good but I didn't think they were that special.

For our main courses, we shared the Saratoga Burger and Mussels Ciopino. I was surprised that the server did not ask us how we wanted our burger cooked. It was a good burger, I suppose. Again, it didn't make a lasting impression. The Mussels were the hit of the evening. The sauce was flavorful and the mussels were plump. I would've loved to have more bread to soak up the sauce.

We felt that we needed some sort of vegetable to balance out the meal so we ordered the asparagus & endive salad. This was a total miss.

4 stars is on the generous side. The space is beautiful and the drinks are the draw here.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Michele was super fun and oh so smooth with his service, and he wasn't even our server. The table next to us got that honor. 

They utilized the space very well, with a bar and table service upstairs and a lounge-like area, smaller bar and more tables downstairs. Lighting is cozy and the interior design is mesmerizing. 

Some of the food were better than others. Drinks were quite off. 

Confused why there were inedible limes placed with our mussels when their juice could have been added in the kitchen with a good squeeze and they were hidden underneath the mussels so adding nothing to the visual plating. Wondering if it's to give the illusion of more volumne in the dish. The meat inside the mussels were also not impressive. Small with some missing entirely, but soup had good flavor and good for dipping bread.

The tater tots were quite different, with the potato were mashed and then set in cubes. Inside is thick, meaty potato and outside is a crispy exterior. Uniquely delicious. 

The burger came with a lot of meat. The pickles were removed because they didn't taste as good and almost took away from what was otherwise a well seasoned dish. The bread was light with a pinch of sweet for the perfect added flavor.

The drinks were a big miss. The martini tasted "weird" and almost as if water had been added. Perhaps the ice had melted a bit too much in the cooler? The sibling rivalry was recommended as being similar to an old fashion. Though not a bad drink, it does not resemble an old fashion. It's lighter and the presence of orange stronger. The wine (though not bad in taste) pouring was almost shameful. Lifted it up to make sure eyes weren't deceiving and there indeed was very little in the glass. Only the European nearby serves a similar shy pouring. Better to just get the bottle.
author: Kimberly H.

description: A must while in San Francisco, best hamburger I've ever had. Also had the Millionaire bacon (pork belly) totally decadent! We walked there from 7th st in SOMA, wouldn't do that again, some sketchy blocks to go through. Restaurant is gorgeous inside. Service is top notch professional.
author: Colleen M.

description:
I decided to plan a bachelorette dinner for six last Saturday. It has become my go-to spot in the area. This place brings so much vibrancy to SF that we don't get enough of; especially when you're not looking to spend a ton of money for a date night or dinner for GNO. The service is great by delivering the family feel when you walk in. Mandy is superb starting at how personable she is and how she makes your experience coming in feeling so warm! 

I would simply put that The Saratoga has the nice/trendy restaurant with the "ma & pop" feel. I highly recommend going in for their amazing cocktails (walking dead!) and their amazing bites (chicken, hamachi, pretzels, and steak!)
author: My N.

description:
Love hanging out this place on a friday night! Awesome cocktail and bartenders. Food is good too but I didn't try the main course but only appetizers.
Def will bring friends here again!
author: Roxy T.

description: Boy, I really wanted to like this joint. Looks swanky, lively vibe, started well...but then the food came. Octopus was way overcooked and just not good. Burger had no flavor- how do you screw up a burger? Drinks were tasty enough, but for the prices? Thank you, but I can get libations just as tasty elsewhere at 2/3 the price. Bartenders were personable and engaging, so def one star for them, but otherwise, a very surprising and expensive fail on multiple fronts. Expected much better considering its pedigree..
author: Evan B.

description:
A MUST 
Very friendly and knowledgeable staff 
Smaller brunch menu but everything on it OUTSTANDING
author: Marion T.

description: I never made it inside to try the food. The overflowing trash can by the front door made me change my mind. The experience begins before a person even enters the premises. How hard can it be to for someone to sweep up the trash before you open? Gross.
author: Sandra W.

description:
3.5 ice cube spheres

I love watching things being built. 

Everyday I would drive down post street and notice this space being built out on Larkin and Post Street....thinking who would build out a space in such a wratch hood.

The metamorphosis into a stunning bar was nothing short of spectacular: especially at night when the lights show off the stunning bar.

Unfortunately the drinks and food don't really live up to the beautiful interior: My two drinks were actually pretty weak and lacked character ( maybe I'm just an alkie?)

 The walking dead didn't have a punch that one would expect with the fruit juices and rum (smugglers cove makes killer rum drinks in contrast)

The Japanese Highball ( I have been a huge fan of Japanese whiskys for many years) really did not display any flavor of Hibiki, or the Suntory blends it was supposed to have. (Nihon Whiskey bar does this amazingly well)

My wife did like here lovely wine so that was nice.

Of the three plates we shared none was really great: 

Sure the fries were fine ( tough to mess up) but the Kale salad was way overdressed and soggy ( the soft poached egg really didn't add anything due to the sogginess).

The Cuban frank was pretty good but the cheese was not melted and was just a cold piece of cheese...this was texturally unappealing compared to all the warm items in the plate.

Probably the best part of The Saratoga was the wonderful warm staff. Each person was truly lovely and a joy to be around...and in a way made the experience pretty special.
If the food had been a tad better I could easily give them a solid 4 stars...So I will be back to check them out again.

Please experience them for yourselves as the vibe is great.
author: David G.

description: best cozy place to sit and best variety of cocktails to drink. due to mandatory yelp condition filling in characters now
author: Jayant S.

description:
Such a fun/trendy place in Tender Nob. The ambiance alone was def a 5. Bar is impressive, wine selections was great. Not too many craft beers but no biggie. The menu is very creative for comfort food. A lot of it is pretty heavy but thats what comfort food is. They def use quality ingredients. 

The tomato burrata is amazing! Salty, cheesy goodness! I saved some and added it to the Kale Salad I got. We also tried a chicken slider that was so good but only came with 1 which I alone couldve ate 2-3. Sadly we were too stuffed for dessert which I had been looking forward to the most. I cant wait to go back for just some small bites and drinks! The menu isn't too veggie friendly but you could make it work!
author: Hetal P.

description: Okay, I'm 55 and I've eaten thousands of burgers in my life.  Best burger ever at the Saratoga.  Amazing bar menu as well.
author: John L.

description:
The owner contacted me and encouraged me to come back and visit them again and assured that I would have a better experience. Since we live in the neighborhood I was willing to come back and try new items on the menu. On my third visit we were greeted by Elizabeth who was very refreshing and got us a table right away. Our server was right on with our drinks and dinner. The whole night was worth the updated 5 starts. Looking forward to coming back soon.

This place is way over rated! I came here for dinner and the service was amazing. Drinks was worth the 5 star and the food was good but not great, never the less I was looking forward to return and try a new dish.
I have given them the 1 star due to their manager rude attitude when I return. I had made a reservation and for some reason she could not find it. She was loud and very rude so I left and went to an amazing restaurant in Union Square. There is just way too many restaurants in San Francisco for me to spend my money and experience this behavior.
author: Paulina C.

description: 4.5 stars - my fiancé found this restaurant heading up Larkin and seeing the massive brown liquor assortment behind the bar.  The bourbon selection was in fact very impressive.  We had the chicken slider which was perfectly fried, and the jumbo asparagus salad, which had a great sauce verte.  For our entrees we had the Saratoga burger (surprisingly with no sides or fries) and the cubano frank which was a niman ranch beef frank covered with pork, cheese and mojo relish.  Everything was very good.  Service was excellent - I wish I asked our server's name but he really paid attention to my dietary restrictions and knew how the dishes were prepared or modified.  Great ambience and huge bar.  The downstairs area was quieter and also had a cozier ambience, with another bar.
author: Vivian W.

description:
What a find. I'd rate The Saratoga well just based on the liquor display behind the bar, a towering glass wall of mostly beautiful whiskeys in every lovely shade of brown imaginable. But that wouldn't be fair, so naturally I had to stop in and experience everything they had to offer. 

My friends and I came in around midnight on a Wednesday, so I can't speak to how busy they get. On out night it was perfect - low key with plenty of time for quality service. Our bartender was a friendly gal who knew the shelves behind her like an encyclopedia. I ordered the Free Trade Agreement (Pisco, Cachaça, Singani, Lemon, Agave, Egg White, Bitters) and couldn't have been happier with my order, plus I genuinely enjoyed watching the process of it being made. The real hit, and this was unanimous, were the 'Toga Tots, a decadent combo of Fiscalini cheddar, chorizo and scallions on top of, well, tots. I instantly regretted offering to share them with the three fellas I was with because they were gone in a flash. 

If you're looking for a nice date spot or a place to quietly appreciate good liquor, The Saratoga would be a top recommendation. I know the tots alone are my kryptonite.
author: Alex L.

description:
Man, I've never Yelped before but my experience here was just so worthy of some praise...

Made a reservation online after reading countless mentions on Eater and Thrillist.  When we arrived we were greeted with a beaming smile, the super sweet host explained our table wasn't ready yet which was fine with us.  Time to grab a drink at the jaw dropping bar!

The incredible back-lit bar is just stunning.  The bartenders were so knowledgeable and didn't mind walking us through their extensive selections and suggesting just the right fit for everyone in our group. 

We were so pleased when the food turned out to be just as good (...better?) than the cocktails!   I loved that the menu seemed to take classic items and add fun quirky twists. We started with the tuna tartare on a fried black rice cake.  SO GOOD!  It kind of tasted like a fried sushi roll.  It was spicy and sweet and earthy but most importantly still tasted light and fresh.  I had the NY Strip for my main and OMG I'm now obsessed.  It comes topped with this creamy cognac peppercorn sauce that is truly to die for.  We ordered a side a fries just so we could mop up every last drop.  Will definitely be dreaming about that sauce for some time.

A few days after we dined at The Saratoga we were reminiscing about our meal, and while the food and drinks were on par with so many other popular restaurants in SF the one thing we all really agreed stood out the most was the hospitality.  From the minute we walked into the building we felt the warm welcoming nature of this place.  The manager even came and checked in on our table, cracked some hilarious jokes, and made us feel special. 

They really have a great team over there and that is what will keep us going back!
author: Mimi V.

description:
This was my first time at The Saratoga.  
We were lucky to get a table right away, usually need to book a reservation. 

We had: 
Toga tots - $8   5 stars
Salmon Crudo - $16  5 stars
Tomato Fondido -$12  over 5 stars.  This was the highlight of the meal! 
S.T corn - $7  3 stars - way too spicy for me.  But if you love spice then this one would be good for you

Was slightly disappointed in the dessert options
We tried the Ho-Ho - $9 and decent but not amazing

I'm also giving the service 5 stars
Everything came out quickly and very friendly staff 

Overall experience was excellent.
author: Rachel S.

description: This is a really nice and upscale place!  We had Sunday brunch, and we really enjoyed it. I recommend trying this place. We will have to go back for dinner sometime.
author: Kyle H.

description:
This location is awesome! The alcoholic collection is amazing. I popped my head in for the 1st time, and I was totally impressed. The ambiance was incredible. Great music great bartenders they even have a downstairs bar. 

I am truly impressed I will definitely be back!
author: Victor G.

description: Excellent !!! All the way around the food is amazing the Ambience is great! music is nice I mean we are visiting from Houston and this is definitely going to be a go to spot that's open till 1 AM. Liz was our waitress she did not miss a beat. Friendly, great service, I was very impressed. Thumbs up!!
author: Jessica F.

description:
Boyah!! I think I found a new go to spot to enjoy delish libations and nice chill atmosphere!

Friends and I rolled in here last night as the last stop to end our Long work week and enjoy a final beverage or two. 

Location wise, it's not the best nighty pedestrian traffic if you will, especially those standing on street corners earning . However, you can find street parking around on Larkin & Post where this cool place stands out.

Walking in, pleasant restaurant/bar staff opening a curtain to let you in this chill/ hip place. The bar with floor to ceiling  shelves and cool chandelier near the stairway pops out in the background from the black walls and ceilings. 

We only had some beverages, no food. The Saratoga had a detailed cocktail and wine menu which is very impressive. Wine & cocktail prices $12-$16 of what we sampled, some libations were great and some were norm. A wee bit over priced in my opinion. Hence the 4 stars.
The service staff were very accommodating and professional. I will be back!
author: Nawar F.

description:
My second visit was tonight.  
Love the place.  Extensive spirit selection and creative bartenders, friendly and professional staff, chicken sandwich and crab Louis special are standouts.  I've tried over a half dozen menu items and loved every single one so far.  Can't wait to try the rest of the menu. 
I prefer the downstairs, where they have a noise suppressing fabric on the walls dampening the noise a bit.  (The all glass upstairs can get pretty loud).  
Menu is shorter than you'd expect, and hidden inside the drink menu but what they do, they do really well.  
Except coffee.  They use some kind of drip system that makes coffee so slowly, it's cold when they get it to your table.  

So definitely go to the Saratoga, it's amazing.  just skip the coffee.
author: Ken W.

description: I'm not a fan of the Loin, but this place is in a ok location. Very cool space. Top shelf drinks. Excellent service and the food is delicious. The bread yummy, the hamachi crudo yummy, the spicy chicken yummy. Awesome 2/8/18
author: Cecilia D.

description:
The doorman, Frederick was kind enough to chat with me (super nice guy) while I waited for my friend to arrive. If you want to impress your date, he suggested ordering "The Walking Dead" cocktail for that "wow" factor. 

My friend ordered it and our server lit it tableside but the flame quickly went kaput. She tried lighting it again, and kaput! 

Bummer....it was like a whiskey d*ck.

If you're coming to The Saratoga for a hawt date, make sure your equipment doesn't go kaput later that night ok? Which means don't go overboard with the drinks at The Saratoga because trust me, you will want to! 

From the owners of Michelin starred Spruce and The Village Pub (Woodside), The Saratoga is beautiful two-story restaurant and bar serving elevated comfort food with a huuuugggge booze list (opened 11/10). If you like whiskeys and rare spirits, this is THE place to go to. I was told they have over 300 whiskeys and there's even a $1,500 shot.

The cocktails are the highlight of The Satatoga. I had the Highball Gin w/ honeydew, tarragon, lemon, tonic ($12): http://bit.ly/2eT5Crn and the Green Goblin: Botanical vodka, green chartreuse, maurin quina, lime, basil ($13): http://bit.ly/2gaHo0I. Both were equally good and well-balanced; the Highball was refreshing while the Green Goblin was more potent. 

As a fernet lover, I was happy to see five rare ones on the list including one from 1950. 

"Where are you ever going to see this Fernet on the menu again?", my friend said. 

Umm, never. 

I caved and ordered a shot at $32 an ounce: http://bit.ly/2fr8K1w. Fernet is a digestive and tastes medicinal (think Chinese herbal drink your mom use to make you drink x 10) and this one was x 100...really smooth and aged. TMI, but I was bloated from the food, and this was like Gas X in a glass (also works like Pepto if needed). 

Solid cocktails aside, my friend and I both agreed that the food needs some work, as well as, the pacing of the courses (we didn't even dig into our salad when our mains arrived). Grand opening kinks are inevitable so I'm sure they'll work it out soon. 

*'Toga Tots w/ fiscalini cheddar, chorizo, scallion ($8): 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2f9721E:
While they were nicely crunchy, they were barely warm and we couldn't taste any of the chorizo. The cheese and sauce could have been more evenly distributed.

*Chicken Liver Toast w/ honeycrisp apple butter, endive, walnuts ($9): 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2g7FTBv.
Deliciously creamy and the bread was nice and crusty. Personally, could have done without all the endive.

*Baby Kale, Quinoa, and Persimmon Salad w/ crispy bacon, egg, gorgonzola dolce ($13): 4 STARS
http://bit.ly/2exSTyW
Our fav dish of the night - greens were fresh and perfectly dressed with a nice salty crunch from the bacon and blanket of creaminess from the perfectly poached egg. 

*Cubano Frank w/ slow-roasted pork, yellow mustard, mojo relish ($15): 3.5 STARS
http://bit.ly/2fPSAvx
The soft buttery toasted bread and the deep fried hot dog was good but the mustard was overwhelming. Also, the swiss overpowered the pork so we couldn't taste it. No sides included. 

*Burger w/ taleggio cheese, slaw, onion bun ($15): My friend ordered the burger which had two thin patties that were cooked to a perfect medium but the copious amount of coleslaw was very salty. No sides included.

*Cracker Jacks: Caramel popcorn, peanuts, maldon salt ($7): 2 STARS
http://bit.ly/2eTcLYB
It was nostalgic to find a prize inside but we didn't like the popcorn. The caramel was not evenly distributed and some clusters were really salty.

*Fried Apple Hand Pie w/ cream cheese frosting ($9): 3 STARS
http://bit.ly/2fNpwpz 
It was just ok. We expected a flakier crust and the cream cheese frosting was too hard to even spread. A glaze dip would be better. 

For having just opened, the FOH staff was definitely on their A-game. Loved our server - she was super friendly, genuine, and attentive without being intrusive. I forgot to get her name but she also works at The Battery. As I was looking for the restroom, a guy (manager?) personally led me to the restroom downstairs. Nice touch. And, of course the doorman - super cool cat, he greeted every single customer who walked through the door with a welcoming smile. 

The Saratoga is going to be the hottest date place in town with its vintage glam vibe, gorgeous illuminated bar (there's two), and floor-to-ceiling chandelier. Even though the downstairs dining area is more formal (white linen clothed tables), it felt a bit claustrophobic so I preferred dining upstairs. It's equally loud both upstairs and downstairs so if you're looking for a quiet, romantic place for dinner, you may want to look elsewhere. 

As for parking...good luck. Take an Uber or Lyft here.  

Highly recommend coming to The Saratoga for drinks. When I win the lottery one day, $1,500 shots at The Saratoga for everyone!

P.S. - This is an unbiased review as we paid for our meal.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Came here wanting the burger, since it was listed on Eater's Burger Heat Map (https://sf.eater.com/maps/best-new-burgers-san-francisco-oakland-berkeley-heatmap). It looked so amazing in the pictures! The Saratoga is also from the same owners as Spruce, another wonderful restaurant with spot on burgers. 

On Thursday, we checked for reservations on Sat. None were available online, but when we called, a 7:15pm reso popped up for them! Score! 

Drinks:
The two had I had were amazing - The Walking Dead (Rum, Lemon, Papaya, Pineapple, Pomegranate, Tiki Bitters), and Green Goblin (Botanical Vodka, Green Chartreuse, Maurin Quina, Lime, Basil). Each cocktail is $14, which I guess is higher than going rate, but the amount of alcohol was perfect. Loved it. Very beautifully crafted drinks - see my pic. For the Walking Dead, they poured rum on the pineapple, and lit it on fire. It was sweet, caramelized, and so good. 

Food:
-YOU MUST GET THE WARM TOMATO DIP!!!! I was expecting something like a warm hummus type thing, but NO. It was a tomato that tasted braised with lots of olive oil, butter, and garlic. Apparently it's some Piedmont, Italy tradition. You dip the wonderful tomato mixture on top of the bread - simply amazing.
-Toga Tots - these tasted like sophisticated carne asada fries! The tater tots are cubed, which is a fun play on food, with cheddar, chorizo, and scallions to top. It definitely tasted like a grown-up version of carne asada fries. If you're into that type of dish, like my bf is, then this is a must.
-Burger - Pretty good, but I'd say that their sibling's Spruce is better. Saratoga's burger felt like it was missing tomato, grilled onions, etc. But the meat was perfect, as well as the cheese. I also liked the shredded lettuce & mayo mixture! There are no add-ons, like Spruce. But also, the restaurant as a whole is trying to achieve something different. This is a bar atmosphere, not a michelin-star neighborhood-gem restaurant. 
-Harissa-spiced Fries - big enough portion to share among 2 people if you're both getting the burger. They were crispy shoestring fries, with seasoning on top. It came with a cucumber lime dip, but just get the ketchup, because it tastes damn good even with the fries seasoned.

Ambiance: 
-The bar is so beautiful, and your eyes can't stay off of it when you enter the restaurant. It has really cool backlighting, so the lights illuminate the drinks, very cool. It was kind of similar to Black Cat (bar in the same area) in a way, with a trendy feel and black furniture/paint. 

Service:
-Excellent. Food came out very quickly, service was attentive, and personable. The bartender who made our drinks came from Spruce, so you know they are well-trained!

I would definitely come back to this restaurant. I think the burger is worth trying, but now that I've had it, the other entrees looked amazing, and I need to try other drinks too. Can't wait!
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Great food, drinks and service. Kinda dressy but easy to get in without a reservation.
author: Rabia H.

description:
The Saratoga just opened a few weeks ago and it's not bad! Great food and  service but..... I didn't like the way they literally plated most of the food we ordered at the same time. I also had my kale salad last and my main entree before. Could do better of spacing the food out and not in random order. 

Things I ordered:
- Crudo 
- Toga Tots
- Chicken Liver Toasts
- Baby Kale, Quinoa, and Persimmon Salad
- The Saratoga Burger:
author: Jenn L.

description:
We were invited to the grand opening, and dinner was on the house!

The restaurant has a cool modern yet speakeasy inspired vibe, ground floor and basement level dining rooms and 2 bars with a full menu being being served. The seats are comfortable, the staff is well dressed and friendly as well as professional. 

We kicked things off with pork belly buns, kale salad, pickle plate, fries, and burger and chicken pallard for the mains. 

I loved the simple, locally sourced menu with some fun twists like use of persimmon, grapefruit, labane, and just well balanced flavors. The burger came out salty so they had to redo, the cheese on it is also very overpowering, it's also served by itself so you have to order a side of fries or whatever and it seems overpriced. Chicken was excellent and fun dish, the rest were solid.

We had a lot of fun trying the cocktails, something they are going to excel at, all we're well balanced and labor intensive, again shows skill and creativity.
author: Inga W.

description:
I came here late a night for a burger, a beer, and a shot.

That's exactly what I got. for $20+ bucks. Was it worth it? Probably not - the beer and shot were average, but the burger was not great. The patty was a little too loose and fell apart when eating too quickly, and there was some sort of horseradish dressing?? or something on the lettuce. After a beer and a shot, sure, I'll have one. Other bars will serve a side, but none to be found here.

Extensive wine/beer/cocktail/sprits menu, but sometimes simpler is better. Old-school fancy ambiance. Not the worst place to be at the end of a night, but let's just say my boi Jack Dorsey knows what's up when he says Alta is his fav. restaurant.
author: Albert C.

description:
WOW! Great experience at The Saratoga, totally pleased with this new spot! A GF and I wanted a night out for drinks/gossip and bites, and decided to check this new place out since it has the "hype." I looked online day before and didn't think I needed to make reservations, but when came around 8pm on Thursday it was pretty packed! They have separate waitlists for the tables and the bar, so make sure to choose where you want to sit. 

We snagged a couple seats at the bar, and were served some amazing "Green Goblin" cocktails, AMAZING! We had two of them each, so were lightly buzzed when we had some of the most delicious Toga Tots, Salmon Crudo (FAV) and warm parker house rolls...buttery and so delicious. By this time we were craving dessert, and was suggested the cracker jacks (custom made in house) but decided for the fancy ho-hos...the bartender (Malcolm) being awesome, gave us a sample of cracker jacks on the house as well! We were STUFFED and so happy with the place. 

It's pretty crowded and definitely the spot to be at, dates, groups whatever. The downstairs is packed as well but more dinner type accommodations, a little too stuffy for me. Thanks to the wonderful and friendly staff, definitely will recommend and be back!
author: Mahsa T.

description: Beautiful bar. Came here on the fly for after dinner drinks. Only negative was the very bright cool toned light upstairs. It was a little off putting and uncomfortable. The light fixtures and decor are quite stunning, but we preferred the cozier, warmer bar downstairs. Our bartender had exceptional knowledge of his collection, particularly whiskeys, and introduced us to Nikka Gin also - which we had never seen. We all enjoyed our drinks, and as for bites, the shishito peppers were undercooked but I appreciated the cherry tomatoes... My friends inhaled the tater tots lol
author: Gabi Taylor R.

description:
This is a great place for drinks or friends meeting up after work. The bar and bartenders are top notch.
My only draw back would be their dinner/food menu. We had drinks Saturday early evening and were hoping to have dinner but the choices were not as extensive as we would have hoped. We did have appetizers and they were fantastic!
author: Pstephan A.

description:
Had to try this new spot in my neighborhood -- and it was a good experience.  It gets busy on weekends, so we called and managed to get squeezed in but strangely enough when we got there -- about half the tables were available.  

I ordered the "Walking Dead" cocktail which is very pretty and pretty entertaining since they light the pineapple on fire. (get your phone ready you IGers and Snapchatters)  I will say it was a bit strong tasting for my taste -- it was hard to drink. (but pretty? lol)  Oh -- FYI their drinks are expensive, mostly around like $15.  

We ordered a bunch of appetizers for the table:  We got the "Toga Tots" which were a big hit with our group -- everyone liked them.  The "Spicy Pork Belly Bun," which was alright.  My personal favorite was the "Chicken Liver Toast" -- this has apples and almonds, and oh my gosh, yum -- so good!  

For my entree I got the "Grilled New Caledonian Blue Prawns," which FYI still has the head attached (if you're a 5 year old like me, this is valuable info).  The prawns were delicious, however the serving size is fairly small.

I would come back for the ambiance and the atmosphere of the restaurant/bar.  The decor is beautiful and modern, and its a gem in the neighborhood (but an expensive gem).  I wouldn't necessarily come for the food, I would probably recommend it for a glass of wine and an appetizer (specifically that Chicken Liver Toast).
author: Michelle S.

description:
Wow the tenderloin is changing fast! This place fancy! Totally a techie spot with the price range, 2 of us dropped in the high $200 to $300 for an evening there, but it was a lovely evening. The drinks were yummy, my favorite was one with a flaming pineapple (sorry forgot the name, look at my photos). 

The food! Surprisingly so good! Both our favorites, Home made tator tots and Salmon Crudo! 
Also had the following, Chicken wings, yummy fall off the bone. Burger, amazingly juicy and flavorful burger, no fuss stuffers, just juicy meat. Mole Fried Chicken, the mole was tasty, good size portion but we were so full already, couldn't enjoy the full experience of it. But then we also ordered some apple pie pocket, it was ok. The hohos were yummy! 

We walked in and was seated within 45minutes on a Friday night around 8:30p.m.
Great staff and experience. The doorman was even cool! Props to him standing in the freezing cold.
author: Karen T.

description: Amazing brunch spot. Was in San Francisco for the weekend . Definitely recommend!!! Was very delicious. Had the Eggs Benedict and Bourbon French toast. Sooo worth it. The service was great too. Can't wait to come back.
author: B R.

description:
I will never return--- our cocktails arrived at our table AFTER our food.  My dining partner ordered the Parker House rolls; they were inedible.  They were tough, hard, evil rolls.  She sent them away.
My hamburger's bun was -burned- and the thin patty barely cooked.  I was too tired to even deal with the bad food, so I ate around it, we got our adjusted bill and got the hell out of there.  
The drinks were good, yet they would have been so much better if they hadn't arrived after our 'dinner' had arrived.
Zero star...
author: Karen W.

description:
Beautiful decor and the same owners as Spruce. The cocktails were amazing - on par with Park Tavern which has the best Manhattan's and Vieux Carre's. The food was decent - I thought the tater tots 'toga tots' were too salty but the salmon crudo was very fresh. Salads were good as well. 

The menu is pretty sparse so most of us got the burger which was pretty good but not the best ever. Service was excellent - I would go for drinks and apps next time.
author: Karen S.

description: I really like this place great first date spot. I got the chicken slider I ordered two I didn't think it would be that big but one is good enough.
author: Honey H.

description:
Came here for a friend's birthday....we were way too many people for the downstairs bar area so we had to split the group between upstairs and downstairs and we made it work. 

It's a beautiful establishment, as noted has 2 floors. The drinks are really good, expertly mixed and they have a very decent whiskey selection. I also tried some of the bar food, specifically the Tater Tots (amazing) and their pork bun (really great, full of porky goodness). Service was also very good.
author: Jordan C.

description: I was looking forward to coming here for awhile and was so elated to finally go. Unfortunately, the experience was less than desirable. We sat down and didn't get any acknowledgement from anyone for 20+ minutes while the two top behind that came in after us was offer water and drinks. Somehow we were the table they chose to ignore. We finally had to flag down a passing busser to ask for our server. He arrived shortly after and coldly took our drink order without saying hello or telling us the specials or offering water.
